subject: Medicine
title: Cancer and Immune Evasion
description: A quick, practical guide to Cancer and Immune Evasion.

hook.text: Cancer cells are your own cells gone rogueâ€”and they've learned to hide from the immune system.

buildup.text: The immune system normally detects and destroys abnormal cells. This process is called immunosurveillance.

discovery.text: Cancer cells evade detection by disguising surface markers or suppressing nearby immune cells.

twist.text: Some tumors create a microenvironment that turns immune cells into allies that protect the tumor.

climax.text: Immunotherapy drugs unmask cancer cells, letting the immune system see and destroy them again.

punchline.text: Cancer hides in plain sight. Immunotherapy rips off the mask.

quiz.question: How do cancer cells evade the immune system?
options: They disguise surface markers and suppress nearby immune cells
They move too fast for immune cells to catch
They produce antibodies that neutralize T cells
